_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Class 1 Div. 1 electric w/in 5 ft. of all transfer (railcar and truck) points w/Class 1 Div. 2 from 5-15 feet, Class 1 Div. 2 w/in 15 ft. of remainder.
_prev_prog_3.Description: The on-site Butane Transloading System provides for the transfer of liquefied butane under pressure from butane railcars.  Up to 8 railcars may be stored on-site [approx. maximum 33,600 gallons of water capacity] with a liquefied butane maximum anticipated fill level of 30,000 gallons.  The liquefied butane is offloaded from a railcar through use of a single portable transloader (transloader is moved from railcar to railcar to transfer butane) to pressurized butane trailers.  The system is designed to minimally meet the requirements of NFPA #58 (2017) for siting and safety/control functions.  Notable safety features include Railcar pressure relief valves, thermal/hydrostatic relief valves, check valves, Railcar excess flow valves, pneumatically actuated attachable Excess flow/emergency shutoff valves (Fisher Type), grounding clamps on transloader, LP transfer hoses on transloader, and pneumatic emergency shutoff valves (Snappy Joe type) which fail closed on pneumatic pressure loss.  Additional protection includes an emergency shutoff system including ESD pushbuttons and remote key FOB actuator, and low-melting point (<250oF) pneumatic supply lines (fire protection).

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Tristar Transload PNW, Inc. - Vancouver Facility complies with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) #58 (2017 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is this facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local laws/codes.  If an emergency were to occur, it is the facility's policy to notify the Vancouver Fire Department as well as the Clark Regional Emergency Services Agency, as necessary.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the Vancouver Fire Department.  This facility has an Emergency Response Plan; however, it does not maintain a trained fire brigade or hazardous material response team on-site to respond to the small initial stages of an emergency.



The Tristar Transload PNW, Inc. - Vancouver Facility is a butane transloading facility (specifically, railcar to truck tanker).  This Risk Management Plan (RMP) covers the butane railcar storage and transloading system only, including the associated piping and storage for up to eight (8) storage tanks (detached railcars).



The Tristar Transload PNW, Inc. - Vancouver Facility complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) accident prevention rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119) and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  This butane railcar storage and transloading system is designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58 and the manufacturer's (TRI-FLO Inc.) instructions.  Railcars meet the U.S. Department of Transportation Federal Railroad Administration design requirements for pressurized tank cars.



This is a new facility; therefore, it has never had an accident involving butane which has resulted in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuation or sheltering in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Tristar Transload PNW, Inc. - Vancouver Facility butane rai

lcar storage and transloading system, it is the policy of the facility to initially contact the Vancouver Fire Department and request their assistance.  The facility personnel are trained.  The facility emergency action plans are coordinated with Vancouver Fire Department and Clark Regional Emergency Services Agency.  The Vancouver Fire Department is aware of the system and its available fire protection systems (site fire extinguishers, emergency shut-off devices and fire hydrants).  The primary hazardous materials response capabilities are provided by the Vancouver Fire Department.



Improvement actions to be considered primarily focus on site security and rail safety measures including continuing safety audits and safety inspections.
